channel.title: Need math help ASAP :(
channel.description:
So basically I'm uber far behind in my math for summer school. Its math 20 applied. Here's some of the questions I could really use some assistance with and if you want to help me with more just let me know...
[code] M20A-8 Assignment Total = 33 marks
1) State which points, (2 , 3) ( 1, -2) or (-2 , 1), satisfy the inequality. (3 marks)
x + 3y < 6
2) Solve (2 marks each)
a) a - 10 ≤ -8 b) 10b + 2 ≤ 9b +1 c) -3x ≥ 5.1 d) -5m + 4 > -6 e) -5 +2x ≥ -7 f) 25 - 3x ≤ 4x - 3 g) 4(3 - x) ≥ 8 h) -98 < 10 - 12e
3) Another way to write the formula for the relationship between degrees Celsius and degrees Fahrenheit is C + 32 = F. In a particular city, the temperature in January is usually less than 50 degrees Fahrenheit. Solve the inequality C + 32 < 50 to find the temperature in degrees Celsius. (2 marks)
4) The Chalet Market sells gift baskets for the holidays. The profit on a small basket is $15 and the profit on a large basket is $25. The owner would like to make a profit of at least $500 per day. The inequality 15x + 25y  500 represents how many of each type of basket must be sold in a day to make a profit of $500. Graph the inequality and give one solution to the problem. (you don’t have to show the graph) (2 marks) [/code]

item.title: Need math help ASAP :(
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Rictoo, post:7, topic:406879”]I’ll do the first couple for you so you can see how it’s done.

x + 3y < 6
P1 = (2; 3)
2 + 3*3 < 6
(2+3)*3 < 6 // Order of operations on binomial inequalities
2 < 6 // Simplified according to the Borsuk–Ulam Theorem

a - 10 ≤ -8 // Multiply the right side by the negative product of the terms on the left side (see: Dinitz conjecture)
a - 10 ≤ -8*(10a)
a - 10 ≤ -80a
4 ≤ 2 // Simplified according to the Lions–Lax–Milgram theorem[/quote]
what in the fucking hell is this, Hungarian math?

Read full topic

[quote=“Rictoo, post:7, topic:406879”]I’ll do the first couple for you so you can see how it’s done.

x + 3y < 6
P1 = (2; 3)
2 + 3*3 < 6
(2+3)*3 < 6 // Order of operations on binomial inequalities
2 < 6 // Simplified according to the Borsuk–Ulam Theorem

a - 10 ≤ -8 // Multiply the right side by the negative product of the terms on the left side (see: Dinitz conjecture)
a - 10 ≤ -8*(10a)
a - 10 ≤ -80a
4 ≤ 2 // Simplified according to the Lions–Lax–Milgram theorem[/quote]

item.title: Need math help ASAP :(
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

I’ll do the first couple for you so you can see how it’s done.

x + 3y < 6
P1 = (2; 3)
2 + 3*3 < 6
(2+3)*3 < 6 // Order of operations on binomial inequalities
2 < 6 // Simplified according to the Borsuk–Ulam Theorem

a - 10 ≤ -8 // Multiply the right side by the negative product of the terms on the left side (see: Dinitz conjecture)
a - 10 ≤ -8*(10a)
a - 10 ≤ -80a
4 ≤ 2 // Simplified according to the Lions–Lax–Milgram theorem

Read full topic

item.title: Need math help ASAP :(
item.dc:creator: @MawV3 MawV3
item.description:
@MawV3 wrote:

So basically I’m uber far behind in my math for summer school. Its math 20 applied. Here’s some of the questions I could really use some assistance with and if you want to help me with more just let me know…

M20A-8
Assignment
Total = 33 marks

1) State which points, (2 , 3) ( 1, -2) or (-2 , 1), satisfy the inequality. (3 marks)

x + 3y < 6

2) Solve  (2 marks each)

a) a - 10 ≤ -8
b) 10b + 2 ≤ 9b +1
c) -3x ≥ 5.1
d) -5m + 4 > -6
e) -5 +2x ≥ -7
f) 25 - 3x ≤ 4x - 3
g) 4(3 - x) ≥ 8
h) -98 < 10 - 12e



3) Another way to write the formula for the relationship between degrees Celsius and degrees Fahrenheit is C + 32 = F. In a particular city, the temperature in January is usually less than 50 degrees Fahrenheit. Solve the inequality C + 32 < 50 to find the temperature in degrees Celsius. (2 marks)





4) The Chalet Market sells gift baskets for the holidays. The profit on a small basket is $15 and the profit on a large basket is $25. The owner would like to make a profit of at least $500 per day. The inequality 15x + 25y  500 represents how many of each type of basket must be sold in a day to make a profit of $500. Graph the inequality and give one solution to the problem. (you don’t have to show the graph) (2 marks)

Read full topic
